quiz.title: Unit 11: International Microeconomics (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics â€” Trade Policy Applications & Synthesis
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Trade Policy Effects, World Price Analysis, Exchange Rates, Trade Arguments, Welfare Calculations

questions.question: When a country imposes an import tariff, the government revenue collected is represented by:
options: The per-unit tariff amount multiplied by the quantity of imports after the tariff is applied.
The entire increase in domestic price multiplied by the total quantity of imports consumed.
The total loss in consumer surplus minus the total gain in domestic producer surplus.
The world price of the good multiplied by the quantity imported after the domestic tariff.
questions.explanation: Tariff revenue is derived from the tax collected on each unit of the good that still enters the country despite the higher price.

questions.question: If world demand for Country A's primary export increases, Country A's terms of trade will:
options: Improve because the price of its exports rises relative to the price of its imported goods.
Worsen because the price of its exports falls relative to the price of its imported goods.
Remain unchanged because international exchange rates will adjust to offset the price change.
Improve only if the country simultaneously reduces its domestic production of the export.
questions.explanation: Terms of trade are defined as the ratio of export prices to import prices; an increase in export prices raises this ratio.

questions.question: Which argument for trade protection is based on the idea that temporary protection allows industries to become competitive?
options: The infant industry argument regarding the development of new domestic sectors.
The national security argument concerning the production of vital military equipment.
The anti-dumping argument focused on preventing predatory pricing by foreign firms.
The environmental standards argument aimed at equalizing regulatory costs for firms.
questions.explanation: The infant industry argument suggests that startups need time to reach economies of scale before facing established global competitors.

questions.question: If the world price of sugar is \$0.50/lb and the domestic price without trade is \$0.75/lb, opening to trade will:
options: Lead the country to import sugar since the world price is lower than the domestic price.
Lead the country to export sugar since the world price is lower than the domestic price.
Have no effect on the domestic market because consumers prefer to buy from local firms.
Cause domestic producers to increase their production to meet new international demand.
questions.explanation: Countries import goods for which they lack a comparative advantage, signaled by a domestic price higher than the world price.

questions.question: A quota that limits imports creates a 'quota rent' which typically accrues to:
options: The specific individuals or firms that hold the legal licenses to import the good.
Domestic consumers who benefit from the increased quality of the limited imports.
The government through the automatic collection of fees similar to an import tariff.
Foreign governments as a form of indirect compensation for the loss in export volume.
questions.explanation: The difference between the world price and the higher domestic price accrues to the license holder as an economic rent.

questions.question: When a large country imposes a tariff, it can improve its terms of trade because:
options: Its reduction in imports is significant enough to lower the world price of the good.
Domestic producers are incentivized to adopt more efficient technologies and methods.
The government can use the tariff revenue to subsidize the production of export goods.
Foreign governments are statistically likely to lower their own tariffs in response.
questions.explanation: By reducing demand significantly, a large country can force foreign exporters to lower their prices to maintain sales.

questions.question: If Country X's currency appreciates against Country Y's currency, Country X's exports to Country Y will:
options: Decrease because Country X's goods become more expensive in Country Y's currency.
Increase because Country X's producers earn a higher profit margin on every unit sold.
Remain unchanged because international trade contracts fix prices regardless of rates.
Increase because Country Y's consumers will have more purchasing power for luxury goods.
questions.explanation: Appreciation makes domestic goods more expensive for foreign buyers, typically reducing the quantity of exports demanded.

questions.question: The deadweight loss from a tariff includes both production and consumption inefficiency because:
options: Resources shift to high-cost domestic production and beneficial consumption is lost.
The administrative costs of collecting the tariff exceed the total revenue generated.
Domestic consumers pay higher prices while domestic producers lose their profit margins.
Foreign producers reduce the quality of their exports to maintain their current prices.
questions.explanation: DWL captures the loss in total surplus from inefficiently producing goods locally that could be bought cheaper abroad, and from consumers buying less.

questions.question: Which scenario justifies trade protection according to the national security argument?
options: Ensuring domestic steel production remains sufficient to supply military equipment.
Protecting the domestic textile industry from low-cost imports to prevent unemployment.
Shielding domestic agricultural producers from the volatility of world market prices.
Preventing foreign firms from dumping consumer electronics at predatory price levels.
questions.explanation: The national security argument focuses on maintaining industries vital for defense to ensure self-sufficiency during conflicts.

questions.question: When trade opens between two countries, total economic welfare increases because:
options: Resources are reallocated according to the comparative advantage of each nation.
The governments of both countries are able to collect more revenue through trade fees.
All domestic producers in both countries gain higher profits from the larger market.
Prices for all traded goods equalize at the highest possible pre-trade domestic level.
questions.explanation: Specialization according to comparative advantage allows for a greater total output and consumption than is possible in autarky.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent synthesis of trade concepts, policy effects, and welfare analysis.
scoreMessages.70: Solid AP-level understanding; review terms of trade and quota rent concepts.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice with trade policy effects and welfare calculations.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on: tariffs create revenue; quotas create rent; currency appreciation hurts exports; terms of trade = export/import prices.
